entry.title: How to modify keyboard layouts easily in Ubuntu
entry.content:
If you want to remap the CAPSLOCK key to the Control key or something else, you will find many tutorials on the internet (most of them are of course for Emacs learners). However, quite a few of them are outdated and unnecessarily complicated (for me). In a modern version of Ubuntu, you can accomplish this easily in the system settings dialog. I believe Ubuntu learned this from Mac.

Here is how (12.04 LTS):

  1. Locate System Settings in the upper right corner of your desktop, and select Keyboard in the popup dialog:

Sorry for the Chinese ... but you should be able to recognize where to click,
after all its a picture
  1. Then goto the Layout Settings in the lower left corner:

  1. You will see Options in the lower right corner:

  1. Here you will find various options concerning the behaviors of special keys:

  1. Now you should find your way of configuring what you want, I simply exchanged ESC and CAPSLOCK. It is really convenient to have this modification, since both Emacs and Vim are heavy ESC key users.

Good luck using Emacs!
